awd_titl_txt: The role of medial prefrontal cortex in motivated social cognition
awd_abstract_narration:
This project explores the neural mechanisms that permit us to evaluate ourselves in the way we would like.  Self-evaluation is a core social-cognitive process that affects healthcare decisions, emotional well-being, interpersonal relations, and productivity at school and work. If we deny a problem exists or view our abilities through rose-colored glasses, we are not likely to seek help or allow adequate time to perform a task. Disordered self-evaluation is a feature of many mental health issues such as depression, schizophrenia, and autism. Currently little is know about how self-evaluation is affected by neurobiological development in the general population or the neurobiological impairments associated with disorders. Our lack of knowledge stems from the fact that neural models of self-evaluation trail far behind psychological models. Thus, there is a great need to develop neurobiological models of self-evaluation. 

The proposed project will use a combination of fMRI, psychological theory, and computational modeling to address two critical bottlenecks that impede development of neural models of self-processing. First, the studies will illuminate the neural architecture of motivational influences on self-evaluation. Motivational influences on self-evaluation play a fundamental role in psychological models yet are currently ignored by neuroscience. Additionally, the studies will disentangle a critical confound present in most of the existing research on self-evaluation. Specifically, the project will examine whether the medial prefrontal cortex, the region most consistently associated with self-evaluation, serves to support socioemotional processing or cognitive properties of social evaluation. Results will transform our conceptualization of the neural basis of disorders such as depression, schizophrenia, and autism which feature disordered self-evaluation but are currently only understood through neural models of other processes. The results will bridge gaps between psychological and neurocognitive models to inform the next generation of self-evaluation research as well as inform related inquiries into reward-processing, selective attention, and decision-making.

por.por_cntn:
Our understanding of the brain basis for many disorders such as depression and addiction is rooted in the emotional aspects of the disorders but that is not the whole story. Depression is associated with persistent negative moods. Substance abuse is associated with uncontrolled impulses toward feeling good or, at least, avoiding bad feelings. However, these disorders are also characterized by failures of self-insight. For example, depressed individuals may have a more negative view of their capabilities than warranted by objective indictors (e.g., thinking you are bad at your job despite your boss giving you positive performance reviews). And individuals with substance abuse problems may overestimate their ability to cope with their problems and subsequently fail to seek treatment. The current research helped advanced our ability to consider neurobiological interventions aimed at bolstering accurate self-insight and insight into other people. Specifically, the project identified neural regions in prefrontal cortex which promote a lack of insight, that is, help people to see themselves and the world in the way they want rather than reality.

The results from this project have recast our understanding of the psychological function of the brain. For example, the ventral anterior cingulate cortex had been previously characterized as a region involved in identifying the rewarding versus punishing things in our lives. However, this project shows that the ventral anterior cingulate cortex is not just a dispassionate detector of objectively rewarding things (that, is things everyone would agree are rewarding). Instead, the ventral anterior cingulate cortex is also involved in identifying what is rewarding to a particular person based on their idiosyncracies (e.g., the chance to paint a disliked person in an unflattering light). One implication of this work is that the ventral anterior cingulate cortex may be important for confirming one's views about the world and, therefore, intervention in this region may help alleviate the tendency of people with depression to see the world through a negative lens.

 Furthermore, the research has shown that the medial prefrontal cortex is important for painting ourselves and our significant others in a positive light (e.g., seeing ourselves and others as having exceptional abilities and qualities) for a different reason than previously thought. Previous theories had suggested that the medial prefrontal cortex played a somewhat distal role by factoring in the greater emotional stakes or greater information we have about ourselves and the people we like. Instead, this region is involved in helping accomplish the desire to paint certain people, including ourselves, in a positive light by straightforwardly imposing an expectation of positivity on our judgments. Therefore, the function of this region may be a valuable point of neurobiological intervention because it may be important to combat its role in expectations that everything is going to be fine when they are not.

Taken together, this project has made appreciable gains in understanding the ways in which the brain permits us to see ourselves and the world not as they are, but in the way we would like to see them. This information is helpful to know as it provides new points to consider for neurobiological intervention for disorders such as depression and addiction which involve failures of self-insight but are currently understood through their other symptoms.
